pr_title: [python-experimental] Make the array items attribute optional

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:CiscoM31/openapi-generator into python-array-item-is-optional

timeline.bodyText: @sebastien-rosset I don't think we need prefix and fullSuffix here. These are for models only (e.g. Pet => MyPetV3). Same for line 901.
timeline.author: wing328

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:CiscoM31/openapi-generator into python-array-item-is-optional

timeline.bodyText: @sebastien-rosset Shall we remove prefix, suffix from this line as well?
timeline.author: wing328

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:CiscoM31/openapi-generator into python-array-item-is-optional

timeline.bodyText:
We also need to include the prefix before these types and the fullSuffix after them.
Can you update it to this?
return prefix + "bool, date, datetime, dict, float, int, list, str, none_type" + fullSuffix;

Or you could include ModelUtils.isAnyTypeSchema(p) in the conditionals on lines:

906
909

And then we wouldn't need this additional if statement because we will correctly return in line 910.
Up to you which way you want to do it.
timeline.author: spacether

replies.bodyText: I specifically removed the prefix based on Wing's feedback. Now my understanding is that prefix/suffix is only used for model, this is done on purpose. But my understanding is limited. If you still think this needs to be added, can you provide a better java doc that explains the exact purpose of the prefix and suffix? And the conditions under which prefix and suffix is set? If I make a change, I'd like to understand why it needs to be done and document it.
replies.author: sebastien-rosset

replies.bodyText:
We also need to include the prefix before these types and the fullSuffix after them.
Can you update it to this?
return prefix + "bool, date, datetime, dict, float, int, list, str, none_type" + fullSuffix;

Or you could include ModelUtils.isAnyTypeSchema(p) in the conditionals on lines:

906
909

And then we wouldn't need this additional if statement because we will correctly return in line 910.
Up to you which way you want to do it.

I think this would make the code more complicate to understand and maintain, I don't think it's worth adding recursion.
replies.author: sebastien-rosset
spacether

replies.bodyText:
So reading through the java doc we have:
    /**
     * Return a string representation of the Python types for the specified schema.
     * Primitive types in the OAS specification are implemented in Python using the corresponding
     * Python primitive types.
     * Composed types (e.g. allAll, oneOf, anyOf) are represented in Python using list of types.
     *
     * @param p The OAS schema.
     * @param prefix prepended to the returned value.
     * @param suffix appended to the returned value.
     * @return a string representation of the Python types
     */


I've read that but that doc does not actually explain anything. It's not usable documentation that provides actionable information. Good doc provides contextual information. Without context, the prefix could be any arbitrary string. What value can the prefix get? Since the doc does not say anything, you have to assume it can be anything. Is it even ASCII? UTF-8? Is it a python type? Or maybe a package name? or 200 other possibilities.
Just to be clear, I'm adding documentation whenever I can to improve.
replies.author: sebastien-rosset

replies.bodyText:
That doc explains that prefix goes in front, suffix goes behind, and what types they are. I am hearing that you want an explanation of the valid values. Reading the function and my explanation shows that the values can be:
prefix "({[" and empty string
suffix "({[" and empty string
They allow us to enclose the python data types in containing characters which define tuples, dicts, and lists. Does that help?
Thank you for adding the documentation when it helps.
Man I have strived to add a lot of documentation and tests to python-experimental in many many places. When your comments start from a place of this is not a good doc, it is discouraging. Can you give me the benefit of the doubt? I am trying to make improvements; the goal is to inform people and provide a useful tool. This generator has a lot more documentation, features, and tests than a lot of others. I am trying hard here.
replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText:
I think this function should be private or protected. The fact that it's public means it can be invoked from anywhere, which means by contract the caller can pass anything, not just "({["
I understand you mean well, and we are all striving to improve the doc and the code, but also when a particular doc sentence is not helpful, I need to say it so we can improve it. Here are some guidelines for good docs: https://www.oracle.com/technical-resources/articles/java/javadoc-tool.html
The doc states this:
@param prefix prepended to the returned value.
From that sentence and the type, you can see the prefix is a string, and the value is just prepended to the return value. But it does not have information about what the prefix is supposed to mean.
replies.author: sebastien-rosset

replies.bodyText:
Sure, I get that.
-This is unclear to me,
-I think that this is missing import information about what characters are allowed
-In the future when you write docs, can you follow this best practice
are all sentences that convey the same intent rather than starting with the much worse "this is not good".
I promise you that me and others will respond better with these types of responses. Let's try to treat each other well?
When people new to python write bad python I don't say "This is not good" I give them specific advice about how it can be improved, and why I think we should make the change.
replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText: Sorry, I was just trying to point out that this particular doc was not helpful. You can see from several of my other PRs that I keep improving the doc, so I don't complain, I just improve the doc.
replies.author: sebastien-rosset

timeline.bodyText:
This is the 3rd location in this function that w have defined this list of all types.
Instead of defining this same info 3 times, how about doing one more recursive call and routing us to the return case on line 903 or 910? That keeps this simpler.
timeline.author: spacether

replies.bodyText: I'm not convinced by your argument. I think recursion will make the code more complicated to understand and troubleshoot. Plus here the inner schema is null, so getTypeString() would have to be invoked with either a null value, or create/use a new AnyType schema
replies.author: sebastien-rosset

replies.bodyText:
Yup, my thought was that one would invoke it with the null Schema input, but AnyType inpht would be better.

line 925 does this same [] wrapping logic
The returned data is the line 903 anytype data, all we would need to add is a null check in line 902
The rest of the function uses recursion

But if this is clearer to you we can keep it this way.
replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText:
I have added code comments and used recursion. Thanks for your input, that helps to improve the doc.
I have put some additional code comments for recursion because I think the recursion complicates readability and maintainability.
replies.author: sebastien-rosset

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:CiscoM31/openapi-generator into python-array-item-is-optional
Add code comments, use recursion for any type
